newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: Environmentalists against pact on forest preservation.
newsitem.headline: Environmentalists against pact on forest preservation.

text.p: In a major switch of positions, key environmental groups have opposed a treaty to preserve the world's forests, saying the timing would produce a weak document.
The stand of more than 70 environmental groups at a news conference near the United Nations on Monday makes them an ally of timber lobbies in the United States, if only for the time being.
"There is no clear evidence that a global forest convention is either necessary or desirable," Bill Mankin, director of the Globel Forest Policy Project, said.

"Until more governments implement their existing commitments to protect forests and use them sustainably, it is difficult to have any confidence that they will effectively implement a new convention, whatever its contents," he said.

An intergovernmental committee begins consultations on Tuesday at the United Nations on protecting the world's forests. Canada, the European Union Indonesia and Malaysia want governments to move toward a treaty on forests.

In a joint statement, environmental groups, such as the Sierra Club, Friends of the Earth, Greenpeace and the National Wildlife Federation, said that a forest treaty negotiated at this time would be dominated by powerful timber and commercial trade interests and would fail to address their behaviour.
The groups said that national initiatives need to be undertaken first because a treaty at this time would only achieve agreement "on the weakest, lowest-common-denominator commitments."

It would "formalize unacceptably weak forst management standards, thereby giving a global green light to unsustainable forest practices and cippling several existing and stronger forest initiatives," the groups said.

Major timber companies also oppose any kind of a treaty because of fears it would result in inspections by U.N. bodies and result in different standards for countries that sign the treaty compared to those who do not.
